trans-unit.source: How to use Azure Blob storage from Java | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Azure Blob storage from Java | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Blob storage to upload, download, list, and delete blob content.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Blob storage to upload, download, list, and delete blob content.

trans-unit.source: Samples written in Java.
trans-unit.target: Samples written in Java.

trans-unit.source: How to use Blob storage from Java
trans-unit.target: How to use Blob storage from Java

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: This article will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Java and use the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][].
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Java and use the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][].

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include **uploading**, **listing**, **downloading**, and **deleting** blobs.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include **uploading**, **listing**, **downloading**, and **deleting** blobs.

trans-unit.source: For more information on blobs, see the [Next Steps](#NextSteps) section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on blobs, see the [Next Steps](#NextSteps) section.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] An SDK is available for developers who are using Azure Storage on Android devices.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] An SDK is available for developers who are using Azure Storage on Android devices.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Azure Storage SDK for Android][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Azure Storage SDK for Android][].

trans-unit.source: Create a Java application
trans-unit.target: Create a Java application

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will use storage features which can be run within a Java application locally, or in code running within a web role or worker role in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will use storage features which can be run within a Java application locally, or in code running within a web role or worker role in Azure.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you will need to install the Java Development Kit (JDK) and create an Azure Storage account in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you will need to install the Java Development Kit (JDK) and create an Azure Storage account in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Once you have done so, you will need to verify that your development system meets the minimum requirements and dependencies which are listed in the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][] repository on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Once you have done so, you will need to verify that your development system meets the minimum requirements and dependencies which are listed in the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][] repository on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: If your system meets those requirements, you can follow the instructions for downloading and installing the Azure Storage Libraries for Java on your system from that repository.
trans-unit.target: If your system meets those requirements, you can follow the instructions for downloading and installing the Azure Storage Libraries for Java on your system from that repository.

trans-unit.source: Once you have completed those tasks, you will be able to create a Java application which uses the examples in this article.
trans-unit.target: Once you have completed those tasks, you will be able to create a Java application which uses the examples in this article.

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to access Blob storage
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to access Blob storage

trans-unit.source: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file where you want to use the Azure Storage APIs to access blobs.
trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file where you want to use the Azure Storage APIs to access blobs.

trans-unit.source: Set up an Azure Storage connection string
trans-unit.target: Set up an Azure Storage connection string

trans-unit.source: An Azure Storage client uses a storage connection string to store
trans-unit.target: An Azure Storage client uses a storage connection string to store

trans-unit.source: endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.
trans-unit.target: endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.

trans-unit.source: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the Primary access key for the storage account listed in the Azure portal for the *AccountName* and *AccountKey* values.
trans-unit.target: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the Primary access key for the storage account listed in the Azure portal for the *AccountName* and *AccountKey* values.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string.

trans-unit.source: In an application running within a role in Microsoft Azure, this string can be stored in the service configuration file, *ServiceConfiguration.cscfg*, and can be accessed with a call to the **RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings** method.
trans-unit.target: In an application running within a role in Microsoft Azure, this string can be stored in the service configuration file, *ServiceConfiguration.cscfg*, and can be accessed with a call to the **RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings** method.

trans-unit.source: The followng example gets the connection string from a **Setting** element named *StorageConnectionString* in the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The followng example gets the connection string from a **Setting** element named *StorageConnectionString* in the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.

trans-unit.source: Create a container
trans-unit.target: Create a container

trans-unit.source: A **CloudBlobClient** object lets you get reference objects for containers and blobs.
trans-unit.target: A **CloudBlobClient** object lets you get reference objects for containers and blobs.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a **CloudBlobClient** object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a **CloudBlobClient** object.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] There are additional ways to create **CloudStorageAccount** objects; for more information, see **CloudStorageAccount** in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] There are additional ways to create **CloudStorageAccount** objects; for more information, see **CloudStorageAccount** in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].

trans-unit.source: Use the **CloudBlobClient** object to get a reference to the container you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the **CloudBlobClient** object to get a reference to the container you want to use.

trans-unit.source: You can create the container if it doesn't exist with the **createIfNotExists** method, which will otherwise return the existing container.
trans-unit.target: You can create the container if it doesn't exist with the **createIfNotExists** method, which will otherwise return the existing container.

trans-unit.source: By default, the new container is private, so you must specify your storage access key (as you did earlier) to download blobs from this container.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new container is private, so you must specify your storage access key (as you did earlier) to download blobs from this container.

trans-unit.source: Optional: Configure a container for public access
trans-unit.target: Optional: Configure a container for public access

trans-unit.source: A container's permissions are configured for private access by default, but you can easily configure a container's permissions to allow public, read-only access for all users on the Internet:
trans-unit.target: A container's permissions are configured for private access by default, but you can easily configure a container's permissions to allow public, read-only access for all users on the Internet:

trans-unit.source: Upload a blob into a container
trans-unit.target: Upload a blob into a container

trans-unit.source: To upload a file to a blob, get a container reference and use it to get a blob reference.
trans-unit.target: To upload a file to a blob, get a container reference and use it to get a blob reference.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream by calling upload on the blob reference.
trans-unit.target: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream by calling upload on the blob reference.

trans-unit.source: This operation will create the blob if it doesn't exist, or overwrite it if it does.
trans-unit.target: This operation will create the blob if it doesn't exist, or overwrite it if it does.

trans-unit.source: The following code sample shows this, and assumes that the container has already been created.
trans-unit.target: The following code sample shows this, and assumes that the container has already been created.

trans-unit.source: List the blobs in a container
trans-unit.target: List the blobs in a container

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference like you did to upload a blob.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference like you did to upload a blob.

trans-unit.source: You can use the container's **listBlobs** method with a **for** loop.
trans-unit.target: You can use the container's **listBlobs** method with a **for** loop.

trans-unit.source: The following code outputs the Uri of each blob in a container to the console.
trans-unit.target: The following code outputs the Uri of each blob in a container to the console.

trans-unit.source: The blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as well.
trans-unit.target: The blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as well.

trans-unit.source: This is so you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like structure.
trans-unit.target: This is so you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like structure.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could have a container named "photos", in which you might upload blobs named "rootphoto1", "2010/photo1", "2010/photo2", and "2011/photo1".
trans-unit.target: For example, you could have a container named "photos", in which you might upload blobs named "rootphoto1", "2010/photo1", "2010/photo2", and "2011/photo1".

trans-unit.source: This would create the virtual directories "2010" and "2011" within the "photos" container.
trans-unit.target: This would create the virtual directories "2010" and "2011" within the "photos" container.

trans-unit.source: When you call **listBlobs** on the "photos" container, the collection returned will contain **CloudBlobDirectory** and **CloudBlob** objects representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.
trans-unit.target: When you call **listBlobs** on the "photos" container, the collection returned will contain **CloudBlobDirectory** and **CloudBlob** objects representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.

trans-unit.source: In this case, directories "2010" and "2011", as well as photo "rootphoto1" would be returned.
trans-unit.target: In this case, directories "2010" and "2011", as well as photo "rootphoto1" would be returned.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **instanceof** operator to distinguish these objects.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **instanceof** operator to distinguish these objects.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can pass in parameters to the **listBlobs** method with
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can pass in parameters to the **listBlobs** method with

trans-unit.source: the **useFlatBlobListing** parameter set to true.
trans-unit.target: the **useFlatBlobListing** parameter set to true.

trans-unit.source: This will result in
trans-unit.target: This will result in

trans-unit.source: every blob being returned, regardless of directory.
trans-unit.target: every blob being returned, regardless of directory.

trans-unit.source: For more
trans-unit.target: For more

trans-unit.source: information, see **CloudBlobContainer.listBlobs** in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].
trans-unit.target: information, see **CloudBlobContainer.listBlobs** in the [Azure Storage Client SDK Reference].

trans-unit.source: Download a blob
trans-unit.target: Download a blob

trans-unit.source: To download blobs, follow the same steps as you did for uploading a blob in order to get a blob reference.
trans-unit.target: To download blobs, follow the same steps as you did for uploading a blob in order to get a blob reference.

trans-unit.source: In the uploading example, you called upload on the blob object.
trans-unit.target: In the uploading example, you called upload on the blob object.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, call download to transfer the blob contents to a stream object such as a **FileOutputStream** that you can use to persist the blob to a local file.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, call download to transfer the blob contents to a stream object such as a **FileOutputStream** that you can use to persist the blob to a local file.

trans-unit.source: Delete a blob
trans-unit.target: Delete a blob

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, get a blob reference, and call **deleteIfExists**.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, get a blob reference, and call **deleteIfExists**.

trans-unit.source: Delete a blob container
trans-unit.target: Delete a blob container

trans-unit.source: Finally, to delete a blob container, get a blob container reference, and
trans-unit.target: Finally, to delete a blob container, get a blob container reference, and

trans-unit.source: call **deleteIfExists**.
trans-unit.target: call **deleteIfExists**.
